I respectfully disagree.  You assume that asserts and test cases are equal
in their importance.  What I want to know is whether or not a test has
passed.  You can count asserts and say that tests have passed, but you do
not know which ones have passed unless you have a failure/error mech. that
tells you which have failed.  IMHO, if a test hasn't failed, it has passed.
If it passed, I don't need reassurance at any level that it passed.  If it
failed, I absolutely want to know which test failed and why (one step at a
time though :)!  This is by far more interesting to me than any other
reporting mech. of the framework.  So, why count asserts?  Perhaps to give
that warm, fuzzy feeling... perhaps for some other reason.  My contention is
that I don't see it is being necessary.  I don't mind having the "plug-in",
however, for those cold Michigan winters when I need to get warm and fuzzy
and don't have a fire.  :)

-Jason

    > Subject: Re: [junit] Reporting more then 1 failed 
    > assertion per test
    > 
    > 
    > Why then does JUnit display the number of test cases? If 
    > it is interesting to know how
    > many test cases the system has passed, then it is also 
    > interesting to know how many
    > asserts have made it. This is especially true if a test 
    > case is something like testMethod(),
    > where the individual asserts verify that various values 
    > of the parameters to method()
    > work (max, min, null, normal, etc). Sure these could all 
    > be individual test cases, but then
    > it becomes difficult to see whether I really have 
    > exhaustively tested my method. Code
    > coverage is not the solution. That only tells me whether 
    > what I have written, opposed to
    > what I should have written, works.
    > 
    > - Tom
    > 
    > Jason Rogers schrieb:
    > 
    > > AAAAAAAAAAAAAAHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    > >
    > > Why do you care?  A test fails or it passes.  Period.
    > >
    > > If you want more, JUnit is probably not the framework 
    > to use.  The framework
    > > is not meant to give warm fuzzy feelings 
    > (interpretation of green bar),
    > > pains in the gut (interpretation of red bar), or minor 
    > headaches (amber
    > > bar?).  It is meant to tell you whether or not the code 
    > works the way you
    > > think it should.  It's a SIMPLE framework for 
    > developers and testers, not a
    > > bogus-meet-all-levels-of-satisfaction-and-feel-goods 
    > reporting tool.
    > >
    > > Sorry for the outburst of frustration.
    > > -Jason

    > > > I think it would be useful in certain cases, sort of
    > > > like "make -k" (keep going if an error is found).

    > exception when an
    > > assertion is not "true".  When an exception is thrown, 
    > "the normal flow of

    > environment attempts to find
    > > an exception handler--a block of code that can handle a

    > > throw an exception at the end of the test method).  But

    > >    assertTrue(obj != null);
    > >   assertTrue(obj.status() == 3);
    > >

    > "NullPointerException"
    > > doesn't help much.
